review.title: Lifted Probabilistic Inference for Asymmetric Graphical Models
review.abstract: Lifted probabilistic inference algorithms have been successfully applied to a large number of symmetric graphical models. Unfortunately, the majority of real-world graphical models is asymmetric. This is even the case for relational representations when evidence is given. Therefore, more recent work in the community moved to making the models symmetric and then applying existing lifted inference algorithms. However, this approach has two shortcomings. First, all existing over-symmetric approximations require a relational representation such as Markov logic networks. Second, the induced symmetries often change the distribution significantly, making the computed probabilities highly biased. We present a framework for probabilistic sampling-based inference that only uses the induced approximate symmetries to propose steps in a Metropolis-Hastings style Markov chain. The framework, therefore, leads to improved probability estimates while remaining unbiased. Experiments demonstrate that the approach outperforms existing MCMC algorithms.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text: However, there are several probabilistic graphical models for which an approximate approach is possible due to (conditional) dependencies and the resulting low treewidth (Darwiche 2009; Koller and Friedman 2009). Examples of the earlier class of models are chains and tree models for which an approximate approach is possible. More recently, the AI community has uncovered additional statistical properties based on symmetries of the graphical model that make inferences tractable (Niepert and Van den Broeck 2014). In the literature, approaches to exploiting these symmetries are often referred to as canceled or symmetry-conscious inference algorithms (Poole 2003; Kersting 2012). While elevated inference algorithms work well for highly symmetric graphical models, they are worse for asymmetric models.

sections.heading: Background
sections.text: We review some background information on concepts and methods that will be used later in the essay.

sections.heading: Group Theory
sections.text: A group is an algebraic structure (G, е), where G is a set that is closed under a binary associative operation, with an identity element and a unique inversion for each element. We often write G instead of (G, е). A permutation group that acts on a set of groups is a group of bijections g: A → B that form a group. Let's be a finite set and let G be a permutation group that acts on B. When we write B and G, we write B to denote the picture of A under G. A cycle (α1 α2... αn) represents the permutation that maps α1 to B, 2 to B 3,... and B to B 1. Any permutation can be written as a product of disjunctive cycles. A generating group R of a group is a subset of group elements, so that each element of the group can be written as the product of an endless number of elements of R and their inversions.

sections.heading: Symmetries of Graphical Models
sections.text: Symmetries of a set of random variables and graphical models have been formally defined in upscale and symmetrical probability theory using concepts from group theory (Niepert 2012b; Bui, Huynh and Riedel 2013). Definition 1. Let X be a set of discrete random variables with distribution π and let us have the set of states (configurations) of X. We say that a permutation group G acting on a group can be a subgroup of another automorphism group for X if and only if for all x variables and all g variables we have these π (x) = π (xg). Note that we do not require that the automorphism group must be maximum, that is, it can be a subgroup of another automorphism group for the same set of random variables.

sections.heading: Exploiting Symmetries for Lifted Inference
sections.text: The emergence of high-level representations of probable graphical models, such as plate models and relational representations (Getoor and Taskar 2007; De Raedt et al. 2008), motivated a new class of upscale inference algorithms (Poole 2003), but these algorithms exploit the high-level structure and symmetries to accelerate inference (Kersting 2012). Surprisingly, even in the absence of conditional independence, they perform tractable inferences.Our current understanding of exact upscale inferences is that syntactic properties of relational representations allow efficient upscale inferences (Van den Broeck 2011; Jaeger and Van den Broeck 2012; Van den Broeck 2013; Gribkoff, Van den Broeck and Suciu 2014).The appendix will review such representations, and in particular the Markov logic. More recently, it has been shown that (partial) interchangeability as a static property of numerous results (Van Rieden Broeck 2014 and Huckenperpert 2014) can explain numerous results in this literature (Van Nieperpert 2012s; Huckeni 2012s).

sections.heading: Mixing Symmetric and Asymmetric Markov Chains
sections.text: We propose a novel MCMC framework that constructs mixtures of Markov chains, where one of the chains is based on the approximate symmetry of the probabilistic model. It assumes a basic Markov chain MB such as the Gibbs chain, the MC-SAT chain (Poon and Domingos 2006) or any other MCMC algorithm. Afterwards, we construct a mixture of the base chain and an orbital-metropolis chain that uses approximate symmetries for its supply distribution. Before we describe the approach in more detail, let us first examine Metropolis samplers.

sections.heading: Metropolis-Hastings Chains
sections.text: The construction of a Metropolis-Hastings-Markov chain is a popular general approach to designing reversible Markov chains = neighbors (MCMC-based estimation of marginal probabilities).Metropolis-Hastings chains are associated with a supply distribution Q (· | x), which is used to suggest a move to the next state, since the current state x is given. The closer the supply distribution is to the estimated distribution π, that is, the closer Q (x | xt) is to π (x) for large t, the better are the convergence properties of the Metropolis-Hastings chain. We first describe the Metropolis algorithm, a special case of the Metropolis-Hastings algorithm (Ha ¼ ggstro � m 2002).Let X be a finite set of random variables with probability distribution and let the set of random variables be x.

sections.heading: Orbital Metropolis Chains
sections.text: We propose a novel class of orbital Metropolis chains that move between approximate symmetries of a distribution. Approximate symmetries form an automorphism group G. We will discuss approaches to obtain such an automorphism group in the section. At this point, we present a novel Markov chain that exploits approximate symmetries. In view of a distribution π via random variables X with state space, and a permutation group G acting randomly, the Orbital Metropolis ChainMS for G performs the following steps: 1. Choose a state of xGt, the orbit of xt, equally randomly; 2. Leave xt + 1 = y with the probability min {π (y) π (x), 1}; 3. Otherwise, leave xt + 1 = x.Note that a permutation group that affects xGt, the orbit of the same state chain, simply moves between unconnected orbits.

sections.heading: Lifted Metropolis-Hastings
sections.text: To obtain an irreducible Markov chain that exploits approximate symmetries, we construct a mixture of (a) some base chainMB with stationary distribution π, which we know to be irreducible and aperiodic; and (b) an orbital Metropolis chain MS. We can prove the following theorem. Theorem 4. Let X be a series of random variables with distribution p and approximate automorphisms G. In addition, let MB be an aperiodic and irreducible Markov chain with stationary distribution p, and let MS be the orbital Metropolis chain for X and G. The mixture of MB and MS is aperiodic, irreducible, and has π as its unique stationary distribution.The mixture of the base chain and the orbital Metropolis chain has several advantages. First, it uses the approximate symmetries of the model that proves to be divisible.

sections.heading: Approximate Symmetries
sections.text: The Lifted Metropolis-Hastings algorithms assume that there is a permutation group G that represents the approximate symmetries. We will now discuss several approaches to calculating such an automorphism. Although it is not possible to go into technical details, we will nonetheless provide clues to the relevant literature. Several techniques exist to calculate the exact symmetries of a graphical model and construct G; see (Niepert 2012b; Bui, Huynh and Riedel 2013). Color refinement algorithms are also studied in exact inferences (Kersting et al 2014). You can find (exact) orbits of random variables for a slightly weaker notion of symmetry called fractional automorphism. These techniques all require a form of exact symmetry to be present in modeling. Capturing similar symmetries is a problem that is largely open.

sections.heading: Experiments
sections.text: The LMH algorithms are implemented in the GAP algebra system, which provides basic algorithms for automorphism groups such as the product replacement algorithm, which allows for evenly testing from the orbits of states (Niepert 2012b). For our initial experiments, we use the standard WebKB data set, consisting of web pages from four computer science departments (Craven and Slattery 2001). The data contains information about about 800 words that appear on 1000 pages, 7 pages and links between web pages. There are 4 folds, one for each university. We use the standard MLN structure for the WebKB domain, which has MLN forms of the form shown above, but for all combinations of labels and words that add up to around 5500 first-order MLN forms. We learn the MLN parameters using Alchemy.We consider a collective classification setting where we want to predict the structure and content of each web page.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text: We have presented a Lifted Metropolis-Hastings algorithm that is capable of mixing two types of Markov chains: the first is an unraised base chain, and the second is an orbital Metropolis chain that moves between roughly symmetric states, allowing the application of advanced inference techniques to asymmetric graphical models.

sections.heading: Markov Logic Networks
sections.text: An atom P (t1,.., tn) consists of a predicate P / n of species n followed by n argumentation terms ti, which are either constants {A, B,..} or logical variables {x, y,.}. A formula combines atoms with connectors (e.g., across,.). A formula is ground if it does not contain logical variables. Fundamentals of a formula are obtained by instantiating variables with certain constants. Many statistical relative languages have been proposed in recent years (Getoor and Taskar 2007; De Raedt et al. 2008). One such formula is Markov logic networks (MLN) (Richardson and Domingos 2006). An MLN is a series of tuples (w, f), where the faculty is a real number representing a formula in first-order logic.

sections.heading: Approximate Automorphism Heuristic
sections.text: Considering an OSA, we construct a series of approximate automorphisms as follows: First, we calculate the exact automorphisms G1 of the OSA. Second, we calculate the variable orbits of G1 and group all the variables that can be mapped into each other. Then, for each orbit O, we construct a set of automorphisms as follows: We greedily search for aO "O" O so that the symmetrical group GO "onO" maximizes the ratio between the number of variables moved (i.e., O "|) and the number of potentials moved, while keeping the number of potentials moved limited by a constant K. This ensures that GO" produces an efficient orbital chain. Finally, we remove O "from O and recurse to O. From this set of symmetrical groups GO" we construct a series of metropolis chains, each with its own set of moving potentials.
